meaning_mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji> there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a <vocabulary>convention</vocabulary> or some kind of <vocabulary>tournament</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>event</vocabulary>.
It's always <kanji>correct</kanji> to say something <kanji>straight</kanji> to another person's face. This is called being <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary>. Are you an honest person?

The <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is your <vocabulary>little finger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pinky finger</vocabulary>. Makes sense, but it's also used for the pinky on your feet. You know, your <vocabulary>pinky toe</vocabulary>.

Remember how 風 can mean "style" as in 和風? Well, this is now <kanji>Western style</kanji> <kanji>style</kanji>, more simply put as <vocabulary>Western style</vocabulary>.

洋風 is used to describe things with a Western look or influence, like 洋風の部屋 (Western-style room) or 洋風スープ (Western-style soup).
When the <kanji>relationship</kanji> is <kanji>good</kanji>, that means you're <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> with that person. You're also on <vocabulary>good terms</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 着 can also mean <kanji>arrive</kanji>? This is the verb version of that meaning, so it means <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>.

We have <kanji>alcohol</kanji> and 好き (like). When you like alcohol a lot, you're probably a <vocabulary>drinker</vocabulary>, or at least an <vocabulary>alcohol lover</vocabulary>.

酒好き literally means "someone who likes alcohol," and while they may drink a lot, the focus is on their enjoyment rather than excess. Compared to 酒飲み, it sounds friendlier and less critical, especially when you add the polite お, as in お酒好き.
To <kanji>imagine</kanji> some sort of an <kanji>image</kanji> in your mind simply means <vocabulary>to imagine</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> is <vocabulary>one hundred million</vocabulary>. That's a lot of zeros.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> <kanji>yen</kanji>! So rich! You have <vocabulary>one hundred million yen</vocabulary>!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>problem</kanji> <kanji>topic</kanji> is the <vocabulary>problem</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's 問題.

A <kanji>doubt</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is caused by having too much <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary>. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

器 refers to a <vocabulary>container</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>bowl</vocabulary> and is often used in culinary contexts. It can also be used metaphorically to describe someone's <vocabulary>capacity</vocabulary> for certain things. For instance, when someone has a small 器, it means they have a limited capacity to handle pressure, stress, or difficulties.

Your <kanji>task</kanji> is to open this pickle <kanji>container</kanji>. Why you? Because you are so <vocabulary>dextrous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary> when it comes to opening pickles.

Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 and meant "music"? Well this is that 楽 again. A <kanji>music</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is something that can produce music. It is a <vocabulary>musical instrument</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>container</kanji>s refer to <vocabulary>tableware</vocabulary>, including <vocabulary>eating utensils</vocabulary>, such as knives, forks, spoons, and chopsticks, as well as <vocabulary>serving utensils</vocabulary>, like plates, bowls, and saucers. Basically, it's stuff you use to eat your food.

A <kanji>power</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> isn't a samurai at all. A Samurai's all about precision, after all. So, imagine someone that's a huge mass of muscle (and fat). This Japanese warrior is all about power... ramming into people as hard as they can to knock them over. This person is a <vocabulary>sumo wrestler</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>lodge</kanji> you're staying in has a <kanji>topic</kanji> around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your <vocabulary>homework</vocabulary>. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere.

The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>lodge</kanji> area is <vocabulary>Shinjuku</vocabulary>, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it.

<kanji>Occurrence</kanji>s and <kanji>feeling</kanji>s make up your <vocabulary>circumstances</vocabulary>. 

事情 is used to describe the <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>situation</vocabulary> behind a particular event or action. If you can't go to a party, for example, you might explain your 事情 by saying that something came up or you aren't feeling well. And if your coworker is expecting a baby, you might consider her 事情 and help reduce her workload.

<kanji>Person</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are the <vocabulary>human feelings</vocabulary> every person has. They're the <vocabulary>humanity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>kindness</vocabulary> you feel toward others. 

人情 is often used in literature to describe the warmth found in human interactions and the heartfelt bonds they create. It literally means natural human emotions, but it's really about the kindness, compassion, and empathy people show toward one another.

You have your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, <reading>KAY</reading>?? (け at the end)), you are asking them to <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> or have <vocabulary>mercy</vocabulary> on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary>. Don't kill me, man!

<kanji>Feeling</kanji>, and more <kanji>feeling</kanji>… You're full of <vocabulary>emotion</vocabulary>! (Unsurprisingly, this can also mean <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>.)

感情 is a more formal, objective-sounding word for human emotions — things like joy, anger, sadness, fear. Compared to 気持ち, it feels less personal and more like you're talking about emotion as a category or state.

If you consider the future <kanji>beforehand</kanji> and <kanji>imagine</kanji> how things will turn out (based on some facts), you will have an informed <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prediction</vocabulary> for it.

予想 refers to an expectation or prediction about the future based on current information or trends, like predicting which candidate will win an upcoming election or estimating future economic conditions.

The past events <kanji>revolve</kanji> around your mind as you <kanji>imagine</kanji> them. That's a <vocabulary>reminiscence</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>recollection</vocabulary> of those times.

回想 refers to the reminiscence or recollection of past experiences or events. It's often used to describe flashback scenes in movies or dramas, as well as moments in literature where characters think back on their past.

When you <kanji>think</kanji> and <kanji>contemplate</kanji> deeply, you're producing something larger, like an <vocabulary>ideology</vocabulary>. This means having a group of, or a single larger, <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>(s) or <vocabulary>idea</vocabulary>(s).

思想 refers to the big ideas or beliefs an individual holds about the world and life. It’s often used to talk about one’s thoughts about philosophy, politics, religion, or other such beliefs.

You know that 飲む is drink, so this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing. Also, 会 means <kanji>meet</kanji>, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a <vocabulary>drinking party</vocabulary>!

Your <kanji>see</kanji>ing is <kanji>return</kanji>ing on something. This verb can be both transitive and intransitive. When it’s transitive, it means <vocabulary>to look back at</vocabulary>, in the sense of looking back at someone who’s behind you, or looking back at your past. When it’s intransitive, it simply means <vocabulary>to look back</vocabulary>, in the sense of looking over your shoulder.

You know 初 means <kanji>first</kanji>, and に can mark a point in time. So 初めに means <vocabulary>at first</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in the beginning</vocabulary>. 

初めに has a lot of overlap with 始めに. But while 始めに is for the beginning of some larger process, 初めに refers more to doing something first or to the initial point of a certain time frame. You might say 初めにアクビをしたのは私です (I was the one who yawned first), for example, or 今年の初めに (at the start of this year).
You know that 初 means "first" This word means <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary>. Think of めて as "meet." Then think "when we met <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary> ____ happened."

<kanji>Wind</kanji> of the <kanji>gods</kanji>. These are <vocabulary>divine winds</vocabulary>. More popularly, this is a word known as <vocabulary>kamikaze</vocabulary>, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji> to something or someone, you're putting out your hand <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> them or <vocabulary>to assist</vocabulary> them.
If you <kanji>profit</kanji> from the <kanji>left</kanji>, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably <vocabulary>left handed</vocabulary>.

Remember how 教育 means "education?" Well, the 育 here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a <kanji>body</kanji> education. What do you call the body education at school? <vocabulary>Physical education</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>PE</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>right</kanji> side of your body is the side you <kanji>profit</kanji> most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're <vocabulary>right handed</vocabulary>.

This is similar to 育つ, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means <vocabulary>to bring up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. You can remember this because of the てる. Your version of bringing a child up involves <reading>tear</reading>ing (てる) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
To <kanji>follow</kanji> then <kanji>attach</kanji> yourself to whoever you're following is <vocabulary>to catch up with</vocabulary> someone.

This is the verb version of the vocab word <vocabulary>戦い</vocabulary>, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to battle</vocabulary>.

追う means "to follow" or “to chase” and かける in this case means “to run,” so this word means <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pursue</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to run after</vocabulary> someone or something.
You hopefully have seen the word 注文 (order, request). This is just the verb version: <vocabulary>to order</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>.

You've hopefully seen 好き by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a 大 (big) like? You <vocabulary>really like</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>like a lot</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>love</vocabulary> something.

This is the same as 好き in that a more literal translation would be <vocabulary>lovable</vocabulary>, but it's generally translated as a verb in English.

Remember how 放す is "to release"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the releasing, something gets released or freed. So this is <vocabulary>to get loose</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be released</vocabulary>.

放れる describes something held in place coming loose and starting to move, like an animal breaking free from its tether or an arrow being released from a bowstring. You know this because it's pretty rare (れる) for something that's restrained to break free from its bonds. Escaping isn't easy, so it only happens on rare occasions.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>feeling</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to feel</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>feeling</kanji>s of <kanji>apologizing</kanji>. Strangely, this word means <vocabulary>thanks</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gratitude</vocabulary>, though. Perhaps someone did something so nice for you that you want to apologize for how many nice things they're doing for you. You are this grateful to them!
The <kanji>fee</kanji> for <kanji>enter</kanji>ing a <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>admission fee</vocabulary>. Gotta pay it if you want to get inside.

The <kanji>fee</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (or money) you have to pay is a <vocabulary>fee</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary>.

You've learned 代金, which generally refers to the money paid for physical goods, but 料金 refers to a fee or charge for using a service — think bus fares, highway tolls, entrance fees, monthly service charges, that kind of thing.
You've already learned 映画 means "movie." A <kanji>public building</kanji> for movies is a <vocabulary>movie theater</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dark</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dark</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>dark</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is an <vocabulary>assassination</vocabulary>. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike.

In the <kanji>dark</kanji> if you try to <kanji>write down</kanji> something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is <vocabulary>memorization</vocabulary>! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing!

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You can add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it much, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often.

The <kanji>signpost</kanji> you have your <kanji>eye</kanji> on is your <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>target</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>objective</vocabulary>. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your journey.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>kill</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to kill</vocabulary>.
When a <kanji>person</kanji> is <kanji>kill</kanji>ed, you have yourself a <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is when you kill yourself. That's <vocabulary>suicide</vocabulary>.

If you know <kanji>all</kanji> of something's <kanji>nature</kanji> then you know it <vocabulary>entirely</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>completely</vocabulary>. If you don't, then you know it <vocabulary>not at all</vocabulary>.

This word is weird. It can mean two opposite things depending on what kind of word comes after it. If it's a negative word, it'll mean "not at all." If it's not negative, it'll mean "entirely." Check out the patterns of use and context sentences for examples.

Something that's <kanji>right</kanji> by its very <kanji>nature</kanji> is <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>. 

当然 is also often used as an expression to mean <vocabulary>of course</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>naturally</vocabulary>. It's used when something is expected or goes without saying, like a confident "yeah, that's how it should be."

To find your <kanji>self</kanji>'s true <kanji>nature</kanji>, go out into <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary>. Go out into the forests and fields, do some reading and thinking, and find your true nature.

This can also mean "natural" when it's used as a な adjective, like in 自然な日本語 (natural Japanese) or 自然な色 (natural color).
If you're <kanji>feeling</kanji> the <kanji>fever</kanji>, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of  <vocabulary>passion</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This is for when a thing is <kanji>hot</kanji>, making this word <vocabulary>hot thing</vocabulary>. When the weather is hot that's 暑い. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.

When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>fever</kanji>ish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of <vocabulary>enthusiasm</vocabulary> about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm!
<kanji>Everyone</kanji> + さん (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary>
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>green</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is the color <vocabulary>green</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>practice</kanji> something to <kanji>learn</kanji> it. That's still called <vocabulary>practice</vocabulary>! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>poem</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>poet</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>poem</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji> is <vocabulary>poetry</vocabulary>. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.

詩歌 used to be for two kinds of poetry called kanshi and waka, but nowadays it's also used for other traditional Japanese poetry forms like tanka, haiku, senryu, and more.

Remember how 社長 is the company president? This uses the same 長 meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since 課 means <kanji>section</kanji>, this is the <vocabulary>section manager</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>apologize</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to apologize</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>prize</kanji> of <kanji>gold</kanji> is so old fashioned. We use cash now, which is why this word means <vocabulary>cash prize</vocabulary>.

What part of your car are <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji>s? The <vocabulary>wheel</vocabulary>s, of course!

But 車輪 isn't just for cars! You'll spot this word rolling along with bicycles, motorcycles, carts, strollers, trolleys… you name it. It has a slightly formal or technical tone, so in everyday talk, you'll more often hear タイヤ (tire) when talking about vehicle wheels.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>"choose"</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>.

Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? Well this is one of them. In sports, you must <kanji>choose</kanji> the best <kanji>doer</kanji> for your team. In the world of sports, these "chosen doers" are the  <vocabulary>pro athlete</vocabulary>s and  <vocabulary>sports player </vocabulary>s.

This is a fun one. <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>silver</kanji> is <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>quicksilver</vocabulary>, if you prefer.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just <vocabulary>silver</vocabulary> (the color).
Time to <kanji>go</kanji> get your <kanji>silver</kanji> from the <vocabulary>bank</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Just <kanji>release</kanji> the <kanji>topic</kanji>... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and <vocabulary>as much as you want</vocabulary>. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next  couple levels.
The <kanji>topic</kanji> that we are <kanji>talk</kanji>ing about is the <vocabulary>topic</vocabulary> that we are talking about. It's the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of our conversation.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>foster</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to foster</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. This can also refer to fostering a skill or ability, so can also mean <vocabulary>to develop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cultivate</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>foster</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> you bring into your family is your <vocabulary>adopted child</vocabulary>.

When you’re taking a <kanji>trip</kanji> to a <kanji>public building</kanji>, you might be staying at a <vocabulary>Japanese inn</vocabulary>. Those were very much public buildings for all kinds of travellers back in the day, when you think about it.

Alternatively, you could call this a <vocabulary>Japanese style hotel</vocabulary>, or just by its Japanese name, <vocabulary>ryokan</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
The <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>front</kanji> is the <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.

A train <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at the train station. They are a <vocabulary>train station employee</vocabulary>. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.

This word uses 長 in the same way as 社長, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this 長 is the boss of the <kanji>station</kanji>, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the <vocabulary>stationmaster</vocabulary> (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).

You know that the kanji 温 means <kanji>warm</kanji>, and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to heat something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warm something up</vocabulary>. It's all about you doing something to another object to make it hot, like putting it in the microwave.
When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something according to <kanji>reason</kanji>, the result is an <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary>.
When the <kanji>reason</kanji> is <kanji>solve</kanji>d, you reach an <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> of something. You reach <vocabulary>comprehension</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to solve</vocabulary>. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super <reading>coo</reading>' (く) to solve things.
A <kanji>lodge</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>. It is also considered to be an <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>mister</kanji> is not just he, it's "mister he," and mister he is your he, your <vocabulary>boyfriend</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is <vocabulary>she</vocabulary>. Also could mean <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>, depending on how it's used.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Keep in mind that 俺 has a more informal and masculine sound than neutral options like 私 and 僕. While it carries a rougher vibe, it's not solely reserved for tough personalities and is very common in casual chats among buddies.

When たち is attached to a word referring to a person, it makes it plural. So, when you attach たち to 俺 (<kanji>I</kanji>), it means <vocabulary>we</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>us</vocabulary>.

Just remember that 俺 is quite casual and rough sounding, so it's best to only use it with close friends (or when you're shaking someone down...).
A <kanji>can</kanji> of <kanji>beer</kanji> (ビール) is a <vocabulary>can beer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>canned beer</vocabulary>. Not a bottled one.
A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>can</kanji> is a can that has nothing but sky in it. It's an <vocabulary>empty can</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tired</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to get tired</vocabulary>. 

疲れる refers to a physical or mental kind of tiredness, like you just worked out or studied a ton, but isn't used to describe sleepiness.

疲れる is "to get tired." This is the noun version, which makes it <vocabulary>tiredness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fatigue</vocabulary>.

疲れ is a more casual version of 疲労, so people commonly choose 疲れ over 疲労 in everyday conversation.

The <kanji>north</kanji> <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is the road you take to get to the northern sea. This is the big northern island of Japan, actually, and it's called <vocabulary>Hokkaido</vocabulary>. It's a very nice place, so be sure to visit for some of the freshest seafood around.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>separate</kanji>, so you can guess the meaning is <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary>.
This is the same as 共有 but the verb version.

This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>meet</kanji>, and it means a <vocabulary>gathering</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary>, as you’d expect! It isn’t really used for the kind of meeting you have at an office, though. It’s more in the sense of a people coming together for a specific purpose, like volunteer <vocabulary>group</vocabulary>, or a birthday <vocabulary>party</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is used as a <kanji>substitute</kanji> for an <kanji>island</kanji>. Which island is it? That's right, <vocabulary>Tashirojima</vocabulary>. Imagine a rice paddy in the middle of the sea, standing in for <vocabulary>Tashiro Island</vocabulary>
When you <kanji>express</kanji> a <kanji>feeling</kanji> it shows on your face. This is called a <vocabulary>facial expression</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle finger</vocabulary>, of course! And because we don't see the difference, it's your <vocabulary>middle toe</vocabulary> too. Stick that up the next time someone makes you mad.
A <kanji>woman</kanji> who is also a <kanji>god</kanji> is a <vocabulary>goddess</vocabulary>.
How can you solve your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji>? With a little extra <vocabulary>schooling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>learning</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>imagine</kanji> something that's somewhat <kanji>determine</kanji>d, that means you already have some sort of <vocabulary>assumption</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> about it.

想定 usually refers to assumptions made in advance about certain conditions or situations. It’s often used when talking about preparing for or anticipating future events, especially ones where planning might be required, like natural disasters.
The <kanji>king</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is the <vocabulary>king</vocabulary>, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you!

Your <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is your <vocabulary>thumb</vocabulary>! It's bigger than your other fingers, so that means it's in charge too! This goes for the fingers on your feet too, I mean, your toes. So the parent toe is your <vocabulary>big toe</vocabulary>.

<kanji>God</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is <vocabulary>God</vocabulary>! Or the <vocabulary>gods</vocabulary>, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.

You know that <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>finger</kanji>? The part I just chopped off? Well that was your <vocabulary>fingertip</vocabulary>! I only had time to get the tip. It used to be on your finger and now it's right here, in my hand. Sorry, I guess. Oh, but don't worry, I'll even things out and get the tip of your toe real quick too.

If something is <kanji>special</kanji> you <kanji>choose</kanji> it. That makes it a <vocabulary>special selection</vocabulary> of yours and it gets a <vocabulary>special prize</vocabulary> that only you could give!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 受 means accept and this verb is related. It means to get accepted, usually into something good like a university or a new job. It can also mean to pass, often in the context of a test or an exam. This is an intransitive verb, so no direct object is needed. A hint for this is that it ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive. Also, be careful: in English you'd use the transitive expression "pass a test," but in Japanese you'd say 試験に受かる. Kind of like saying you pass in the exam — so it's still intransitive!

The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Uranus</vocabulary>. Knowledge of Greek mythology will definitely help you here, because the English name is a reference to the Greek god of the skies, and the Japanese name is a direct translation of that!

You have the kanji for <kanji>empty</kanji>, so this verb means <vocabulary>to become empty</vocabulary>. 

It can also have a slightly different meaning when it's read differently, but you'll learn this through other words later on, so don't worry about it for now.
